Class Slice

Namespace
Flex.Smoothlake.FlexLib
Assembly
FlexLib.dll

Represents a receiver/transmitter channel (slice) in a FlexRadio device.

public class Slice : ObservableObject, INotifyPropertyChanged
Inheritance
object

Slice

object.ReferenceEquals(object, object)

Examples

// Create and configure a slice
radio.RequestSliceFromRadio();
await Task.Delay(500);

var slice = radio.SliceList.FirstOrDefault();
if (slice != null)
{
    slice.Freq = 14.200;           // Tune to 14.200 MHz
    slice.Mode = "USB";            // Set to Upper Sideband
    slice.FilterLow = 200;         // Set filter low cut
    slice.FilterHigh = 2800;       // Set filter high cut
    slice.Active = true;           // Activate slice
}

Remarks

A slice is an independent receiver or transmitter channel that can be tuned to any frequency within the radio's capabilities. Modern FlexRadio devices support multiple simultaneous slices (typically up to 8), allowing monitoring of different frequencies or modes at the same time.

Each slice has its own:

  • Frequency and mode settings
  • Filter configuration
  • Audio gain and routing
  • AGC settings
  • Antenna selection
  • Processing features (NR, NB, ANF, APF)

Slices are created by calling Radio.RequestSliceFromRadio and removed with RemoveSlice(Slice). This class implements INotifyPropertyChanged for data binding support.

Freq

Gets or sets the frequency of the slice in megahertz (MHz).

public double Freq { get; set; }

Property Value

double

The frequency in MHz. Valid range depends on radio model and configuration, typically from 0.03 MHz to 77 MHz (direct sampling) and 122.88 MHz to 245.76 MHz.

Examples

// Tune to 14.200 MHz (20m band)
slice.Freq = 14.200;

// Tune to 146.52 MHz (2m simplex)
slice.Freq = 146.52;

// Monitor frequency changes
slice.PropertyChanged += (s, e) =>
{
    if (e.PropertyName == "Freq")
        Console.WriteLine($"Now tuned to: {slice.Freq:F6} MHz");
};

Remarks

Setting this property sends a command to the radio to tune the slice to the specified frequency. The actual tuned frequency may differ slightly due to radio hardware constraints.

If the slice is locked (Lock is true), setting this property has no effect.

This property raises PropertyChanged when the frequency changes.

See Also
Lock
